Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH : Species pool influences on the structure and function of fungal symbiont communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to explain the diversity and species composition of local ecosystems it is necessary to account for species distributions across larger areas. Processes occurring over broad spatial and temporal scales, such as geographic isolation and species evolution, drive these regional patterns and determine the regional species pool, or group of species that could potentially occupy a location. This project will use experiments to determine whether local communities or species from large regional areas explain the number and kinds of fungi associated with plants and their roots. Because these fungi are ubiquitous, they are globally important drivers of nutrient cycling and ecosystem productivity. The scientific workforce will be strengthened through support for the education and training of a doctoral student and participation of undergraduates from underrepresented groups. The project will contribute to improved horticulture and conservation.

The regional species pool will affect local community assembly in multiple ways. This problem will be addressed for fungal symbionts associated with the roots of an endemic Hawaiian plant, Vaccinium calycinum. Using plant-fungal microcosms, experimental symbiont species pools will be introduced to sterile seedlings, varying the number of fungal species along with the mean age and environmental heterogeneity of the sites from which the symbionts were initially isolated. High-throughput molecular methods will be used in combination with physical measurements and analytical chemistry to assess the realized local symbiont community composition within roots. Three hypotheses will be tested: (1) older or more environmentally heterogeneous regions will result in greater functional diversity in the regional species pool; (2) species pools from older or more environmentally heterogeneous regions will result in greater realized local diversity relative to the size of the regional species pool; (3) the richness and functional diversity of the regional species pool will be the primary driver of symbiotic function, measured as the host plant's biomass and nutrient accumulation. The geologic age and environmental heterogeneity of a region will be linked to local community assembly and function via the composition of the regional species pool.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding to support a portion of co-PI Devin Leopold’s doctoral dissertation research. Specifically, the award was used to undertake a laboratory experiment to test whether the age of the species pool influences the relationship between regional and local diversity, using experimental communities of plant-associated fungi. The fungi were isolated from several forest sites in Hawaii that varied in the soil age, which allowed the investigators to experimentally construct species pools of different ages of the sites that the fungal species were isolated from.

In this experiment, the investigators found that local species diversity increased when communities were comprised of fungi from older sites. However, species from older sites were also less functionally diverse, suggesting that increased local diversity was due to equalizing similarity, rather than greater niche differentiation.

The results have been published in Leopold’s Stanford University Doctoral Dissertation, "Temporal determinants of fungal community assembly.” The results were also presented in a public dissertation defense, at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America, and at an invited seminar for the Department of Botany and Plant Pathology at Oregon State University. A manuscript is currently in preparation for submission to a peer reviewed journal.

Understanding the forces that create and maintain biodiversity in ecological communities remains a central question in the field of ecology. Results from the project supported by this award suggest that the relative importance of niche differentiation and equalizing similarity as species coexistence mechanisms may depend on the length of shared evolutionary history among the constituent species.

The project supported by this award increased the breadth and potential impact of co-PI Leopold’s dissertation research. Carrying out the required experiments also involved Leopold gaining expertise in new laboratory methods such as phenotypic microarrays.
